headline.main: Aftermath of the Keating Verdicts: Damage Control, Political Glee

results.snippet: The Keating Five case moved today from the Senate Ethics Committee to the unpredictable arena of American politics, with the five Senators struggling to contain the damage while consultants were trading ideas about how to use the issue in the next...

byline.original: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Keating Five case moved today from the Senate Ethics Committee to the unpredictable arena of American politics, with the five Senators struggling to contain the damage while consultants were trading ideas about how to use the issue in the next elections. Even the Senators' backers acknowledged that the committee's findings would be damaging at the very least. After a 14-month inquiry into the five men's links to Charles H. Keating Jr., the savings and loan executive, the panel said Wednesday that there was substantial evidence of wrongdoing by Senator Alan Cranston, and it issued milder reproofs to the other four.

headline.main: NASA Reduces Cost and Role Of Its Orbiting Space Station

results.snippet: A simpler, more modest plan for NASA's space station is taking shape after budget cuts and the discovery of design flaws sent architects back to the drawing board.    The orbiting outpost, first proposed by President Ronald Reagan seven years ago,...
results.lead_paragraph: A simpler, more modest plan for NASA's space station is taking shape after budget cuts and the discovery of design flaws sent architects back to the drawing board. The orbiting outpost, first proposed by President Ronald Reagan seven years ago, is still largely a castle in the clouds, even though $3.9 billion has been spent on studies and prototype parts.

results.snippet: They won't exactly be alone together, but it will be a sweet moment for MARK LEE and DR. N. JAN DAVIS when they become the first married couple in space. After some review, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's management decided to...
results.lead_paragraph: They won't exactly be alone together, but it will be a sweet moment for MARK LEE and DR. N. JAN DAVIS when they become the first married couple in space. After some review, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's management decided to let the couple fly on the Spacelab mission to which they were assigned before they were married. In 1989 Mr. Lee, a lieutenant colonel in the Air Force, and Dr. Davis, an engineer, were assigned to fly on the Endeavour, a new space shuttle scheduled for September 1992. They were married in January. "There was an unwritten policy not to put husbands and wives on the same flight," said BARBARA SCHWARTZ, a NASA spokeswoman. "This does not change our policy." The agency has 79 astronauts and 23 astronaut candidates, including three married couples. Colonel Lee, 38 years old, will be the payload commander on a joint Japanese-American mission, which will have a crew of seven. He made a shuttle flight in 1989, but it would be the first shuttle flight for Dr. Davis, 37, who became an astronaut in 1988.

headline.main: Army Pilot's Death Stuns Her New Jersey Neighbors

results.snippet: This suburb of 8,000 prides itself on its sense of family and on its local heroes, like the astronaut Wally Schirra, for whom a small park near the heart of town is dedicated. This week Maj. Marie T. Rossi joined those heroes.   In the space of a...
results.lead_paragraph: This suburb of 8,000 prides itself on its sense of family and on its local heroes, like the astronaut Wally Schirra, for whom a small park near the heart of town is dedicated. This week Maj. Marie T. Rossi joined those heroes. In the space of a few days, Major Rossi, an Army helicopter pilot, personalized the Persian Gulf war for people both here and across the country in a way that left many with a deep sense of loss.

headline.main: What the Best-Dressed Astronaut Will Now Wear

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HAMILTON STANDARD DIVISION OF UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP

results.snippet: While many products, from automobiles to appliances, have been redesigned to reduce weight, when it comes to space suits for astronauts, the nation's space program has left the weight issue behind.    During NASA's Apollo space program in the...
results.lead_paragraph: While many products, from automobiles to appliances, have been redesigned to reduce weight, when it comes to space suits for astronauts, the nation's space program has left the weight issue behind. During NASA's Apollo space program in the 1960's and 70's, weight was a major concern because of the gravity involved in lunar missions. But in flying shuttle missions, gravity is no longer an issue. In a weightless environment, heavier, less expensive materials can be used in space suits, said the Hamilton Standards division of the United Technologies Corporation, the nation's leading maker of the suits.

results.snippet: As currently proposed, a scaled-down space station would be inadequate for performing its principal research objectives, two studies by scientific groups have concluded.   One study, by the Space Studies Board of the National Research Council, was...

byline.original: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: As currently proposed, a scaled-down space station would be inadequate for performing its principal research objectives, two studies by scientific groups have concluded. One study, by the Space Studies Board of the National Research Council, was more pessimistic about the scientific usefulness of the new design than the other, by the White House science adviser's office. That study said the space station could be justified with a few modifications to enhance its role of studying humans in space.

results.snippet: The space agency officially unveiled plans today for a streamlined space station that would be smaller, cheaper and easier to build. It would be completed by the turn of the century.   Responding to directives of Congress, the National Aeronautics...
results.lead_paragraph: The space agency officially unveiled plans today for a streamlined space station that would be smaller, cheaper and easier to build. It would be completed by the turn of the century. Responding to directives of Congress, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the plan should cut the total cost of the station to $30 billion through 1999, a decrease of $8 billion from previous estimates.

headline.main: Cut-Down Station May Fall Short on Space Biology

results.snippet: A LITTLE-KNOWN story of the space age, untold by laconic astronauts schooled to set aside emotion and play down danger, is just how bad weightlessness can be.   While logging more than 50,000 hours in space over three decades, American astronauts...
results.lead_paragraph: A LITTLE-KNOWN story of the space age, untold by laconic astronauts schooled to set aside emotion and play down danger, is just how bad weightlessness can be. While logging more than 50,000 hours in space over three decades, American astronauts have suffered nausea, anemia, lethargy, loss of appetite, headaches, disorientation, motion sickness, heart palpitations, fatigue, depression, weakened defenses against infectious disease and a loss of blood volume, muscle mass and bone.
